Award.AwardTitle: Astroparticle Physics with the VERITAS and CTA Gamma-Ray Observatories
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation. Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe, and can be used to test fundamental physics. This award supports scientists at the University of Delaware to carry out gamma-ray astrophysics research using a currently operating observatory and participate in the planning and development of a next-generation gamma-ray observatory. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), located in southern Arizona, is designed to perform high sensitivity pointed observations of both Galactic and extragalactic sources. The University of Delaware group will work on hardware and calibration tasks for VERITAS as well as analysis and interpretation of the scientific data from Galactic gamma-ray sources. The group is also involved in the technology development and scientific planning for the Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA), an international gamma-ray observatory currently in the prototyping stage. The group will continue to organize and host the "Fermi Summer School," a two-week high energy astrophysics course for graduate students and post-docs. They will also continue to engage in a broad range of efforts in education and public outreach.

The University of Delaware group will conduct both scientific analysis and hardware-related activities. They will use gamma-ray observations with VERITAS to study supernova remnants, gamma-ray binary systems, and new gamma-ray sources identified by the complementary High Altitude Water Cherenkov Observatory. They will also conduct prompt VERITAS follow-up observations to search for gamma-ray emission from sources of astrophysical neutrinos identified by IceCube, and mine the VERITAS archive for gamma-ray counterparts to the enigmatic Fast Radio Bursts. The group will work on the maintenance and calibration of VERITAS. They are involved with the hardware maintenance of the upgraded camera, and the development of a new calibration device. Finally, the group will participate in commissioning of the CTA prototype telescope at the VERITAS site. They will also lead the scientific planning for Galactic gamma-ray studies with CTA.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award provided continuing support for the research activities of the University of Delaware gamma-ray astrophysics group. The group's research primarily uses data from the Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), an array of four gamma-ray telescopes located at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory in Arizona. We are also helping to develop a next-generation facility, the Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA). Gamma-ray photons are produced in the extreme astrophysical environments associated with neutron stars, black holes, astrophysical jets and supernova explosions. When they interact in the Earth's atmosphere, they trigger a cascade of high energy particles which in turn produce a flash of blue Cherenkov light, lasting just a few billionths of a second. Gamma-ray telescopes record this brief flash, and use it to reconstruct the arrival direction and energy of the original gamma-ray.

Using VERITAS observations, the Delaware group has studied high energy emission processes from numerous astrophysical objects. Among these are Cassiopeia A, the remains of a star which exploded around 350 years ago. Our observations provide compelling evidence that cosmic ray protons are being accelerated up to TeV energies in this object. Our most remarkable result from this grant period is the discovery of gamma-ray emission from a binary system with a 50-year orbital period. The binary comprises a massive star and a compact neutron star, and gamma-ray emission is only observed for a few months around the time of closest approach. This unique observation will not be possible again until 2067.

The Delaware group has contributed to the maintenance, calibration and operation of the NSF-funded VERITAS array, and to the data analysis software tools which are required to interpret the observations. We have also contributed to the development of a new dual-mirror telescope located at the VERITAS site: a prototype for one of the telescope designs being considered for CTA. Our analysis, which used coincident VERITAS observations to help identify gamma-ray candidate events, led to the first detection of a gamma-ray source (the Crab Nebula) with this new instrument.

In collaboration with scientists from NASA Goddard, members of the group also organized an annual summer school in Delaware (the Fermi Summer School), which provides instruction to graduate students and post-doctoral scholars from around the world. Students are taught how to analyze gamma-ray observations, and provided with an overview of the astrophysical sources and processes which can produces such high-energy photons. We have also taken part in an annual masterclass for local high school students, in collaboration with the Delaware IceCube group.
